prior_works.title: Unbalanced optimal transport: dynamic and Kantorovich formulations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper introduced the dynamic continuity-equation-with-source formulation of unbalanced OT that the RUOT objective in the current work directly adopts to model growth and death from snapshots.

prior_works.title: Scaling algorithms for unbalanced optimal transport problems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: It provided the entropic/KL regularization and generalized Sinkhorn framework for unbalanced OT that underpins the paper’s regularized UOT (RUOT) formulation and serves as the algorithmic starting point the authors extend to learn continuous stochastic dynamics.

prior_works.title: Optimal-transport analysis of single-cell gene expression identifies developmental trajectories in reprogramming and differentiation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Waddington-OT is the primary single-cell baseline using unbalanced OT to infer trajectories but requires externally specified proliferation/death rates; the present work replaces this assumption by learning growth and transitions directly via RUOT.

prior_works.title: A survey of the Schrödinger problem and some of its connections with optimal transport
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This survey formalized the equivalence between entropic OT and Schrödinger bridges and the associated dynamic viewpoint, which the paper leverages to connect RUOT with SB to infer stochastic dynamics from snapshot marginals.

prior_works.title: Diffusion Schrödinger Bridge with Score Matching for Sample Transport
prior_works.relationship_sentence: It demonstrated how to learn continuous-time stochastic dynamics between distributions via Schrödinger bridges and score matching, directly inspiring the paper’s SB-based learning-from-snapshots strategy that is extended to the unbalanced setting.

prior_works.title: Optimal transport in the space of measures: The Hellinger–Kantorovich distance
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work introduced a dynamic unbalanced OT geometry that combines transport with creation/annihilation (Fisher–Rao), informing the paper’s regularization of growth/death when learning RUOT-driven dynamics.

prior_works.title: A computational fluid mechanics solution to the Monge–Kantorovich mass transfer problem
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The Benamou–Brenier dynamic action formulation is the base dynamic OT framework that RUOT generalizes with a source term and regularization, enabling the paper’s continuous-time trajectory inference from snapshots.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core innovation—learning continuous unbalanced stochastic dynamics directly from snapshot data by solving a regularized unbalanced OT (RUOT) problem and tying it to Schrödinger bridges—rests on two intertwined lines of prior work. On the OT side, Benamou–Brenier introduced the dynamic action-minimization formulation of OT, which Chizat et al. extended to the unbalanced setting via a continuity equation with a source term, providing the precise birth–death modeling structure RUOT requires. Liero–Mielke–Savaré’s Hellinger–Kantorovich framework further established a principled geometry for combining transport with creation/annihilation, guiding the paper’s choice of regularization for stable inference of growth and decay. Algorithmically, Chizat et al.’s scaling methods for unbalanced OT laid the groundwork for entropic/KL-regularized objectives and iterative solvers that the present work generalizes with deep parameterizations to handle high-dimensional data and to recover continuous-time dynamics. On the stochastic/dynamical side, Léonard’s survey elucidated the equivalence between entropic OT and Schrödinger bridges, enabling the authors to formalize and analyze the RUOT–SB connection. Modern ML developments in SB, particularly De Bortoli et al.’s score-matching approach to learning SDEs from marginals, directly inspired the data-driven recovery of stochastic dynamics from snapshots. Finally, Waddington-OT established unbalanced OT as a practical single-cell baseline but required external proliferation/death rates; the present method fills this gap by learning growth and transitions end-to-end from data, eliminating false transitions and improving trajectory fidelity.
